Fields.DialogueText: How are you today, Captain? Good, I hope?
You still haven't stopped looking at that letter, have you?
There's just a lot on my mind, Lieutenant.
I understand, Captain. This may seem obvious, but have you considered writing a return letter to the admiral?

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps. I suppose it seems reasonable, but I haven't the slightest idea how to respond to Admiral Stein.

Fields.DialogueText: How about you take a break from it, and we'll discuss it later?
That does sound like a good idea.
*ALARM*
That's one way to take our minds off it...
Heh. Forgive me if I don't thank the Morganas for showing up.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Good advice.
Do I really have to? Do I?

Fields.DialogueText: Uh... I'm not the captain... I just... I was trying to help... er...
I'd be happy to help if I could.
You're welcome, Captain.
Up to more scheming in there, spy?
What are you talking about?
Those drawings there. Who gave you that sketchpad? No prisoner in the forepeak is allowed any writing utensils.
One of the guards gave it to me because I asked for it. I wanted to sketch some pictures in here.
Give it here, spy!
You'll never let that go, will you?
Nein. Do I seem like the type of girl that would let something as serious as spying and the endangerment of my ship be forgiven so easily?
I suppose not. Fine.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: If the prisoner is even telling us the truth about the guard.
It's just some paper and a pencil.
We definitely need to tighten up security in the forepeak.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm off to find that guard, Kapitän.
So were the letters between her and that mechanic. Remember how those caused a few little problems?
Good point, Hans.
Oh! Good point, Kapitän! I like the way you think.
I assure you, Kapitän, I'll take care of it.
You're the first one in the mess again, Hans. Diligent about meals as ever, I see.
I enjoy my meals, chef. So einfach ist das. Besides, a girl such as myself needs her sweets in order to operate efficiently.
Well, then - you're in luck, for we have plenty this afternoon. The cooks and I have been up for hours now prepping a variety of desserts.
Excellent! How about you throw in my usual pudding pretzel?
Sorry, Hans, but the captain just took the last one.
Was?! And you didn't bother making more for me?
It was only a few minutes ago. I couldn't have possibly made some more already.
Ugh! Fine. Please see that you don't forget my food next time.
I will warn you, Kapitän, not to take the last pudding pretzel in the cafeteria again without first making sure I've had one.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't know it was the last one!
Still got a few bites left. Want the rest of it?
Captain's privilege.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph!
It would have been thoughtful and prudent to ask, Kapitän!
I... I suppose that's almost considerate of you, but... I'll pass, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
That last battle was a bit of an ordeal, wouldn't you say?
The captain has been distracted lately, so...
Das ist keine Entschuldigung! Our leader really needs to focus more.
How about you go say so? Better you than me.
Oh, I plan to. This self-pitying and fretting does not bode well with me.
I'll go look for-
I'm right here. There's no need to go scrounging about the ship.
What has gotten you all discombobulated? You do realize we have a ship to run.

Fields.MenuText: My apologies to the both of you, but I assure you I am much better now.

Fields.DialogueText: We still need to talk. Ever since you received that letter you haven't been the same.
Look, Captain. I realize family business and hardships are a great burden, but you can always discuss issues with us.
*ALARM*
Soon.
Good. I will be waiting in your quarters after this.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Talking about your commanding officer behind their back is unprofessional, Hans.
I don't want to have this conversation with you right now.

Fields.DialogueText: Then you're not the only unprofessional one on the ship today. Congratulations, Kapitän.
I see...
So you wanted to talk?
Ja. I need to know what's been bothering you recently. What was in that letter you received?
Nothing really. Just your standard naval correspondence.
I didn't want to take liberties, but I will need to read that letter. Just to make sure everything checks out.

Fields.MenuText: Very well.

Fields.DialogueText: Give it here.
So Admiral Stein is thinking of court-martialing you? Launching an investigation?
Apparently so. First test of the Neutrality Fleet protocols, that would be.
I understand the admiral's concerns - having spies infiltrate our ship is potentially dangerous.
... But it was my fault that a spy was able to get aboard our ship.
Two spies, actually.
Another heartwarming reminder.
*ALARM*
I'll read through this again, and we can continue this later. Right now we have something more... urgent.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You don't trust me to read a letter?
Thanks. I could use a second set of eyes.

Fields.DialogueText: Just let me help you. That's all it is.
You're welcome. Happy to help.
So I'm reminded. I've also been reminded that I have assumed personal responsibility for crew enlistment outside of traditional German channels.
The argument is that I'm either incompetent or tacitly complicit.
It's mostly political, I think. There are people out there who wouldn't cry at the thought of a court-martial bringing my career to an early end. Or just discrediting the idea of international crews.
How is he recovering, nurse?
He's doing better now. Yesterday he awoke from his coma, and he seems to be resting comfortably.
Well, he gets one more day to rest - it's straight to the forepeak after tomorrow.
He's being detained? Why?
Albert Vogel has been exposed as a spy, and we are currently working on procedures to handle the situation.
I see. Does Lieutenant Cardy know about this?
That little tart is also a spy! She and Albert are partners!
Really?! That's serious business, then.
Yeah. We're trying to find a way to deal with them.
Can't you just send them to another ship, or to a detainment center on land?
As it stands, we've got no available ships for a transfer. The seas have become increasingly dangerous, and enemies are everywhere.
*ALARM*
Speaking of enemies, let's go handle this. Schnell.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to get rid of them.
Would you want to take custody of scum like them on your ship? I don't think so.
Better if we keep them here, where we can deal with it ourselves.

Fields.DialogueText: If you think that's best, Captain.
Oh...
As a nurse, I try to take care of anybody, no matter what I think of them.
That said, is there room for two of them in the forepeak?
I'm investigating some rather creative partitions. It's easier if you don't care if they can't sit down.
Hans...
As you requested, I've typed up the notes about some of the unusual physiological responses we observed during the coma. I hope it helps.
I'm sure it will. Danke.
"Unusual physiological responses?" Sounds like an exhausting kind of coma.
Leutnant Schmidt? Wir müssen reden!
Gibt es ein Problem?
I've asked around the ship, and it's been suggested that Schmidt is the one who gave our prisoner drawing materials.
I... ja. Who told you?
I have my methods of finding information, and you're not privy to know them.
Quite so.
Kapitän, Leutnant Schmidt has compromised the security of our crew and must be reprimanded.
But I didn't do anything wrong! I merely gave her some paper and a pencil.
Sie ist eine Gefangene! Sie bekommt nichts ohne meine ausdrückliche Erlaubnis! Hatte ich meine Erlaubnis erteilt?
Nein.
Then you're in trouble.
Hans, I hope we both agree making him swim back to Flensburg is pointless - so why not confine him to his quarters?
Jawohl, Herr Kapitän!
Can I see you in my office as soon as you're free, Hans?
Ja. However, I sense that we have something quite urgent to handle first!
@BATTLE
Danke! Happy to hear that, Kapitän.
He deserved worse for aiding a spy.
Happy to do the dirty work, Kapitän. We'll keep your precious hands clean, shall we?

Fields.MenuText: I like how you handled that.
A bit harsh.
Thanks for taking the lead there. You've got a better shouting voice than I do.

Fields.DialogueText: I second the question. What's up?
Is this true?
Agreed.
I want to apologize for my recent inattention to my duties. I'll admit that the possibility of a court-martial has been a distraction.
An apology? Finally. What next?
I've spent the last few days composing a letter to Admiral Stein explaining my situation - and how we allowed spies onto our ship.
And you hope that might avert the court-martial?

Fields.MenuText: It can't hurt to be forthcoming with the investigation. Maybe the admiral will be lenient.

Fields.DialogueText: What about the Morgana indoctrination situation?
I've heard from some of my sisters that there's a growing list of known and suspected cases. As I'm sure you know.
Yeah. Any insights you'd care to offer?
Fortunately, I have a theory that might let us track them down.
Great, let me hear it.
*ALARM*
Natürlich. Right after this.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Worth a shot, right?
Maybe not, but I still want the chance to explain myself to the admiral.

Fields.DialogueText: Some do become quite soft as they age.
That makes sense, tactically.
Only to explain yourself again at a court-martial? Hmm...
You remember my idea to trap the Morganas?
I wouldn't mind discussing it again in some detail.
*Sigh* I predict that an attack will once again interrupt me telling it to you.
*ALARM*
Hm! Quite sharp of me.
@BATTLE
This is rather odd - seeing you all here... talking.
I realize things have been very stressful lately, but we all agreed to put aside work for an hour to enjoy this meal.
Great idea!
I had Chef Bruno prepare some hearty entrees and desserts for us.
I thought such a frivolous undertaking would represent an unnecessary waste, but the other officers begged me to relent.
She's not fibbing either, captain. She really thought it was a waste of time.
We always have pressing matters to attend to... but I am putting aside business for food and friendship.
Really? That seems so unlike you, Hans.
Consider yourself lucky. Besides, it's what friends do, right?
I'm honored to be considered a friend to the both of you.
Chef! Wir sind bereit!
Here come the meals! Also, Hans, desserts are on their way, too.
Join us, Chef?
Really? Thanks, Captain.
You work just as hard as everyone here, so why not take a break?

Fields.MenuText: All right, how about we start talking less and eating more?
With all the delicious food, where do we start?
Just make sure you leave enough of Hans' favorites for her.

Fields.DialogueText: I never thought you'd ask.
Wherever your gaze falls.
I am glad that you see it my way.
Well, here's to a good meal and good friends.
Eating more it is.
With the first course, traditionally.
I concur.
I do not feel well, Kapitän.
I am sorry to hear that. What's the matter?
Perhaps I ate too much at that last meal.  I wanted to compensate for what I missed that time you stole my pretzel, but the indigestion is the price I paid.
*ALARM*
Ach! Natürlich, the Morganas hate me!
@BATTLE
Ah, visiting your little prisoner? To what do I owe the pleasure? Here to offer more insults and threats?
If that's what it requires to keep you in line, then yes.
Look, I know I made a huge mistake. I never should have been a spy - but I am done with that life now!
Espionage is a life you can never run from. Once a spy, always a spy.
Why are you really here?
The Kapitän and I wish to speak with you.
Hello, Rita. I understand the awkwardness of this whole situation.
I promised to put in a good word for you if you assisted me. I'm repeating the offer now.
But I thought I helped you already.
It wasn't enough.

Fields.MenuText: I'm afraid she's right, Rita. I will be seeking your continued cooperation

Fields.DialogueText: What kind of support do you need, and how can I trust you to help me?
You're going to help us with the Morgana situation.
The first thing we need of you is to convince Albert to assist us. He will be critical in this endeavor.
Very well. I will help you.
Good. I'll give you a briefing soon enough. Be ready.
Take a little time to let your guts settle.

Fields.MenuText: Easy, Hans.
Damn right.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph!

Fields.MenuText: For what it's worth, I'm not even unsympathetic to the Chinese cause. I just wish you'd found another way to advance it.
I believe you did what you thought was right. However stupid it may have been.
I'll keep this brief.

Fields.DialogueText: Our enemy is relentless, Hans. Got any suggestions for dealing with the Morganas?
Natürlich. My plan is quite simple, but it is a long shot.
What's that?
I have a theory that those who are indoctrinated - at least in the manner Vogel was - are able to see what the Morganas see, though probably just for a short amount of time.
So you really think Albert might have clues on the whereabouts of the Morganas? Farfetched... but not entirely impossible.

Fields.MenuText: Have you had any luck with it so far? He's been conscious for a while.

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't spoken to him directly about this yet... but I have a strong feeling about this.
I'm not sure I like the implications of this. Morganas brainwashing human beings is bad enough - especially the cases that seem to involve surgical intervention.
But two-way communication? Shared sensory experience?
Ja. It seems as though they're learning how to build spies.
*ALARM*
Right. We'll follow with your theory, then.
Sehr gut.
@BATTLE
Hmph. Your sarcasm will not increase our chances of success, Kapitän.
Certainly, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Great. I love low-percentage strategies.
Explain it to me.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly.
And you think that... why?
I've been monitoring him. Even when he was unconscious, he seemed occasionally to be responding to verifiable stimuli - including flinching when star shells detonated outside.
Huh. I'm not sure that's an ironclad case, but I admire your diligence.
In one case, we were even able to document pupil dilation during the event - as though he was looking into a bright light as the shell burst. As I presume his Morgana puppeteer was.
Danke.
Glad you have included me in this plan of yours to tackle the Morganas, Hans.
How could I not? You are simply the best person to assist me.
Never a moment too dull or serious to abuse sarcasm, is there?
Nein. Plus if we fail, I need someone to blame.
Great, and maybe I'll be exiled from my homeland and live on an island paradise.
Was that you being sarcastic?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. I thought it was pretty clear.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, you need practice, because that was horrible.
Anyway, joking aside, any further word from the admiral? Are you still at risk of a court-martial?
Yes, there's been word - and it's good. Tempers have cooled.
First we must speak with the two spies.
Very well.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Who, me? What's this "sarcasm" you keep talking about?
I know you are, but what am I?

Fields.DialogueText: Childish, Kapitän. I preferred the sarcasm.
Ha! *snort* Every now and then, you do surprise me, Kapitän.
Now, what about our Morgana problem?
I don't suppose it hurt. It also helped that we caught our spies before they did any real harm and made them useful.
I assume that winning a half-dozen battles over the course of his investigation helped make the case that your recruitment protocols work?
I'm glad you're awake, Albert. Do you remember anything?
Nein. Not really. There were too many voices inside my head for me to pick anything that stood out.
What kind of voices?
Who are these people?

Fields.MenuText: I'm captain of this ship, and technically you are now a prisoner unless you cooperate with us.

Fields.DialogueText: They know who we are, Albert. There is no need to deny it from here on out.
How?
We were able to decode all of the messages between you and Rita. We know you're spies.
However, instead of sending you off to a detainment center where you will be subject to the harsh judgment of the German government, I am asking you to cooperate with us.
I'm listening, but I can't guarantee anything.
Those "voices" in your head that you spoke of were from a Morgana indoctrinator. A dangerous enemy capable of controlling one's thoughts. Now we need your help to find them.
In other words, you were being brainwashed. Do you have any recollection of this?
Please, Albert! Just tell them what you know. It's the only way we might get a lighter sentence.
Very well. I remember having difficulties thinking independently, and there are huge chunks of my memories I cannot recall.
That's probably when he was being controlled, Kapitän. What happens if he doesn't help us?
Then we'll have no choice but to lock him in the forepeak - and hand him over to German authorities at a convenient port. He's no use to us.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I guess your injuries really messed up your head, huh?
You're a terrible liar.

Fields.DialogueText: That might have something to do with it.
Huh?
What are you talking about?
Ja, ja. It's my deck and I'll do with it what I want.

Fields.MenuText: Why does he bother you so much?

Fields.DialogueText: He is a detained spy. Why do I NEED a reason?
*ALARM*
Best not to answer that.
@BATTLE
I'm glad you're doing better now, Albert. You had me really worried.
Sorry to have worried you, Rita. Things have been very strange lately.
They have, but I'm happy you're here with me on this ship. How do you feel overall?
Much better. My arm has recovered and my memories are returning, though there are still patches that I can't recall.
Have you thought about helping us out?
Us? You've agreed to helping the ship and its crew?
Yes. The captain of this ship has been very lenient. That's more than we can ask for as spies.
Sie hat recht, traitor. Usually spies discovered by the German Navy are immediately imprisoned for life... or worse, tortured.
While you're mulling that over, I want you to come with me.
Me? Why?
If you're a good of a mechanic as your girlfriend here says you are, then you'll be able to help me with something.
What is it?
Something related to the rudders. Just come along. It's not a request. It's an order.
Just go and see what she wants.
Schnell!
*Some time later*
I think my work on the rudders is done. How do you feel?
Like a suspicious foreign agent has handled my extremities, but that was to be expected.
You keep tapping your foot like that, you'll put a hole in the deck.

Fields.MenuText: Have some patience. We'll get what we need from him soon.
I want to throw him overboard, too.

Fields.DialogueText: Is that an order, Kapitän? Can I throw him overboard?
And if he doesn't?
Heh.
I tire of waiting for Albert to give us something useful.
Captain, Albert Vogel is ready to speak to you.
Good. Bring him in.
I've spoken to Rita, and I've agreed to assist you in any way I can. Just make sure that she's safe after everything is done.
I'll do what I can. So tell me what you know about the Morganas.
While I was... while I wasn't myself, I saw things. I don't understand all of it.
Elaborate.
I can't explain it, but I think it is where the Morgana indoctrinators are stationed.

Fields.MenuText: How do I know you're telling me the truth?

Fields.DialogueText: I am merely telling you what I saw and felt. Nothing more and nothing less. Do what you will with the information.
Setting the bugs aside for a second - can you sense the Morganas now?
I think something is closing in on us.
What?
*ALARM*
Morgana ships sighted, Captain!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: It's possible you're seeing what they want you to see.
That could be valuable information.

Fields.DialogueText: It's possible I've lost my mind. I know how it sounds, Captain.
That's why I'm sharing it.
I don't *want* to understand all of it.
I believe it. But I hope you understand enough to give us something.
I saw... images of their fleet. One ship in particular had a peculiar way about it.
Wait. Explain. Are we talking about human crew?
No! No, not at all. Though... I think humans have come in and out? One or two?
But the indoctrinators I'm talking about are... I see them as insects. They crawl onto you, or into you, and they whisper. And eventually they just drown everything out, and... and...
I think...
Hans? Albert thinks we have another Morgana group approaching. Can you confirm?
Technically, I think you could say that he's confirming my own observations.
*ALARM*
That said, we don't have much data. He could still just be making lucky guesses.
Either way, time to battle.
@BATTLE
Lieutenant, where are the rest of our engineers? I want our damage control teams to respond more quickly after combat.
They should be here. Maybe they've been delayed...
Where's Hans, then? Is she still at the bridge?
I'm not sure, Captain. I'll go have a look.
Go find her while I head below. I want us squared away quickly.
What are you doing down here?
Assisting the mechanics with this leak.
He was one of the first on the scene here when the leak was discovered, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Who let you out of the sick bay?

Fields.DialogueText: I left of my own volition. Look, I just want to help with the ship repairs.
Adler, keep him with you at all times, and try and stop the leaks as soon as possible.
Aye, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: How's your arm... and your head?
You'd better be making repairs, not sabotage.

Fields.DialogueText: Good enough to patch one leak already.
I'm trying to help, Captain.
Maybe. But I've got him under medical observation, and he definitely seems to be straining his system when he claims to be making contact with these things.
Nice job on recovering from the last Morgana battle. The ship got squared away quickly.
You speak as if my efficiency still surprises you. Kapitän, I know how to do my job well.
I'm sure you do. So do you have any idea how the enemy were able to sneak up on us?
It was me who led them here.
Was? You led them to us? How?
Let me explain! It wasn't intentional. I think they're tracking me through my thoughts.
Elaborate, Albert.
Whatever they did to me... whatever they put into me, it's dying, but it's not dead.
Believe me, I know. You've been thorough. And I don't remember how they got to me. But, trust me, there's something still... in there. I'm trying to use it, but they are too.
Permission to throw him overboard?

Fields.MenuText: Of course not, Hans. He can help us, I'm sure.

Fields.DialogueText: I can. I swear.
What else can you tell us?
Like I said, the Morganas know where I am, but I also know where they are.
All of them?
Nein. I only know the location of one of the Morgana ships, my indoctrinator.
Is there a name for this ship?
I'm not sure.
*ALARM*
Looks like we've got another battle. Let's go, Hans.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Tempting...
There's definitely an argument for sticking him on an island and using him as bait.

Fields.DialogueText: I need a good reason not to do it, and quickly...
You're running out of time to save yourself, spy.
The Morganas can track me, but I can track them down as well.
Albert... we haven't found any entry wounds on you that would be consistent with a Morgana bug-thing burrowing under your skin.
... Anywhere else.
And no anomalies in any natural points of entry. Nothing in your nose, your throat, your ears.
You've spoken to Erich Steinbrinck? Or, rather, her Belle?
Ja. Quite productive to compare notes with my sisters, Kapitän.
What information did she have?
She relayed word of another incident of Morgana influence, actually.
She had also discovered a brainwashed crewmember among her crew.
Same bug hallucinations?
Erich is skeptical that such people could be used to track Morgana forces, but she offered her assistance.
We need all the help we can get.
Let's just hope Albert isn't just playing us for fools. I still don't trust him.
He was able to detect a few Morgana ships coming after us. That at least proves he's telling us the half-truth.

Fields.MenuText: For now, that's the best we can hope for.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Or it could have been a lucky guess.
We should trust him.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't enjoy doing things by halves.
Genau. Don't rule out that possibility.
Nein. He's just trying to save his own neck.
It's unclear. He also fell into a coma - and, unlike our spy, he has not yet recovered.
Interesting. I'd been led to believe that the coma and the... possession were unrelated.
Perhaps they are. Perhaps an unscheduled coma is what saved Albert.
So have you two finally decided to be civil towards each other?
Ja. Somewhat.
In my defense, I'm not the one being belligerent or unruly.
You're still an enemy spy to me, no matter how much you assist us with this matter.
I WAS a spy! Not anymore.
So, if you escaped, you wouldn't go back to Canton with your little girlfriend and share our secrets?
I don't plan to.
Liar.
Okay, so I guess "civil" was an overstatement. I'm ordering you both to avoid killing each other while we sort out the Morganas.
Very well.
Was this the life you had in mind when you decided to become a spy?
Arguing with an uppity girl about phantom ships? Not a chance.
Tread carefully.
*ALARM*
Morganas, Hans. Let's get to battle stations.
@BATTLE
Rita just wanted China to be able to defend itself against the Morganas without just opening the door further to the Japanese. That seemed fair to me.
What's this urgent news you were talking about, Lieutenant?
We've lost contact with the task force, Captain.
When was our last contact?
I last spoke to them a few hours ago on the radio. There was interference, but they were in... I don't know, some kind of a dangerous predicament.
What kind of predicament?
They mentioned something about being cornered.
Well, we need to find them at once.
What if they are already lost to us?

Fields.MenuText: Not if we can get there in time.

Fields.DialogueText: They will not go down without a fight.
Plot the course to their last known position. I expect this will run us across Morgana traffic, but we'll take the risk.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What a stupid question to ask.
You lost radio contact, and we're going to investigate. Don't lose your composure.

Fields.DialogueText: Sorry, Captain.... I wasn't thinking.
Of course, Captain.
Right. Right.
Ja, Kapitän.
So... your connection with the Morganas. Still active? Do you know where they are?
With every passing day it gets weaker, but I was able to locate an approximate area where the Morgana ship may be.
Are you sure? This better not be a trick.

Fields.MenuText: We'll have to trust him, Hans.

Fields.DialogueText: Ich verstehe.
Where is the enemy?
Head southwest. The Morgana ship is anywhere from forty to sixty nautical miles from here.
*ALARM*
Captain, enemy ships approaching!
They're probably here to stop us from reaching the fleet.
Not a chance that is going to happen!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We'll keep him on a short leash, Hans.
Agreed.

Fields.DialogueText: Consequences will be severe if we are betrayed.
And I will hold that leash tightly in my grip.
As we keep heading southwest, my sense of the Morgana ship is getting stronger.
Natürlich, it is in your interest to say that... especially if you aim to get us all killed.
*ALARM*
As if to prove me right.
Or me. Fight on to find out!
@BATTLE
Great work, Hans. We were able to successfully take out all enemy ships.
There are more where they came from.

Fields.MenuText: Do you need a quick break? You should probably rest before the next inevitable battle.

Fields.DialogueText: A quick run to the mess hall for a pretzel sounds good. Perhaps I'll do that.
You'll be pleased to know there are plenty of pretzels left. Refuel and prepare for the final showdown, Hans.
Learning that Albert was telling the truth might be the most shocking part of the day...

Fields.MenuText: Save your strength, Hans.
We've earned a break.

Fields.DialogueText: I have an idea for that.
Some food might help.
Are we almost there?
Maybe.
Maybe?!
*ALARM*
Perhaps that's them... Hard to say.
I truly hope Hans Lody was wrong about you.
@BATTLE
So, are you sure we are headed towards your Morgana ship, Albert?
I can't say, because I've just lost all mental connection with them. Hopefully the path we're on will lead us to them.
Perhaps that's something we should have explored sooner.
What are you saying?
I'm saying that when all this is done, if I survive, I am not returning to my family, or to China, or even the Soviet Union. I want to be away from this world.
I see.
... Are *you* going to return home?
Nein. If we even make it out of Germany after all of this, I think we should find a quiet place to start over.
You have no idea how happy I am to hear that.
All right, you two, enough with the sentimental chattering. Get to your stations and keep your hands where I can see them.
... You look better, for what it's worth.
Ja. Whatever happens now, I feel... an odd kind of freedom.
Freedom...

Fields.MenuText: It's okay, Hans. They're not doing any harm.
Seconded.
I have ear plugs if you need them, Hans. Very useful for crew drama.

Fields.DialogueText: ... If you say so.
Probably unwise, but I can understand the appeal.
Sorry.
There it is, Captain! There is the Morgana indoctrination ship trailing Erich Steinbrinck.
It seems Albert was correct.
I suppose so, Captain. Amazing, really...
Give it everything we've got. And keep them away from our allies!
Aye, Captain.
Schau! Look there! More ships are coming over the horizon.
What's left of the task force is surrounded by more support ships than we thought.
What do you think, Hans?

Fields.MenuText: Should we take on the indoctrination ship first?
Should we assist Erich Steinbrinck first?
Is there some strategy here I'm not seeing?

Fields.DialogueText: That ship should be our prime target.
Erich is out of danger with our arrival. I'd say we should take on the indoctrination ship.
Nein, I'd say the indoctrination Morgana is our best bet.
*ALARM*
Let's hit them hard!
@BATTLE
Very well.
Those escorts are putting up a lot of resistance, but now we've got our chance, Captain.
@BATTLE
Whew! The sky seems clearer now, doesn't it?
Ja. A wonderful addition to a well-fought battle.
It really has been a pleasure working with you, Hans.
I must say I feel the same, Kapitän. I'm glad we were able to assist Erich.

Fields.MenuText: What will you do now?
Do you think you've done Germany proud?
I hope the assistance of Rita and Albert has warmed you to them.

Fields.DialogueText: I think a vacation is in order. Maybe a nice trip the coast of Italy.
Technically that will be up to Germany to decide, but I am confident I have performed above and beyond.
It couldn't very well have made my view of them any worse.
Now how about we enjoy this beautiful weather with some of my favorite desserts?
That would be wonderful. Lead the way to the mess.
That does sound amazing.
For what it's worth, you've done me proud, Hans.
Danke, Kapitän. I appreciate that!
Move us in to engage the main force, Lieutenant.
With pleasure, Kapitän!
